It stars [[Carol Burnett]], [[Glenda Jackson]], [[James Garner]], [[Lauren Bacall]], and [[Paul Dooley]], and was written by Altman, Dooley and Frank Barhydt.{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/77555/Health/full-credits.html|title=Health|work=[[Turner Classic Movies]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]] ([[Time Warner]])|location=[[Atlanta]]|accessdate=October 24, 2016}} The film's title is an acronym for "Happiness, Energy, and Longevity through Health". A parody and satire of the U.S. political scene of the time, ''HealtH'' is set at a [[health food]] convention at a [[Florida]] luxury hotel, where a powerful political organization is deciding on a new president. The election is rife with backroom deals and scandal; a businessman, Colonel Cody, is out to [[vote rigging|rig the votes]] and the outcome. [[Dick Cavett]] and [[Dinah Shore]], two television [[talk show]] personalities of the time, are mentioned prominently in the film. ''HealtH'' was made by Robert Altman's company, Lion's Gate Films (no relation to [[Lionsgate Films]]), in early 1979. It was the director's last film for the [[20th Century Fox|20th Century-Fox]] studio, which shelved its official release for over two years. Despite this, it received festival showings and a brief Los Angeles run during 1980. The film was broadcast on various U.S. television stations over the years, including [[The Movie Channel]] and [[Fox Movie Channel]], but has never been issued on home video. ==Plot== Bearing similarities to Altman's 1975 film ''[[Nashville (film)|Nashville]]'',{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/robertaltmanssub0000self/page/|url-access=registration|quote=Robert Altman's HealtH.|last=Self|first=Robert T.|title=Robert Altman's Subliminal Reality|page=[https://archive.org/details/robertaltmanssub0000self/page/ xix]|isbn=0-8166-3790-3|year=2002|accessdate=2010-04-28|publisher=[[University of Minnesota Press]]}} along with a plotless structure,{{cite book|last=Sterritt|first=David|title=Robert Altman: Interviews|isbn=1-57806-187-3|year=2000|publisher=[[University Press of Mississippi]]}}{{rp|128}} ''HealtH'' chronicles the progress of a health-food convention held at a luxury hotel in [[St Pete Beach]], Florida. As the convention takes place, the members of an organization called HealtH hold a campaign to find out who will become its President. (Their name stands for "Happiness, Energy and Longevity through Health"; it also serves as their slogan.{{rp|113}}) The candidates are Esther Brill, an 83-year-old afflicted with narcolepsy who calls herself "the first lady of health"; Isabella Garnell, who is serious against [[commercialism]] and [[materialism]]; and Dr. Harold (Gil) Gainey, a salesperson-turned-[[independent (politician)|independent]].{{rp|82}}{{cite book|last=Plecki|first=Gerard|title=Robert Altman|isbn=0-8057-9303-8|year=1985|location=Boston|publisher=Twayne Publishers (G.K. Hall & Company/[[ITT Corporation|ITT]])|url=https://archive.org/details/robertaltman0000plec}}{{rp|113}} On the first day of the conference, [[The Steinettes]] (a female [[Quartet#Popular music|quartet]] dressed in green and yellow) introduce Dick Cavett, who is hosting [[The Dick Cavett Show|his show]] on location and covering the details of the event.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gcciAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IO4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5069,1837656&dq=dick+cavett+robert+altman&hl=en |last=Ebert|first=Roger|authorlink=Roger Ebert|title=Altman's new film: It's very healthy|date=1979-05-19|accessdate=2010-05-01|work=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|page=41}} He interviews Gloria Burbank and Esther Brill, two of the candidates competing for the new Presidency of the HealtH organization. Burbank, a [[White House]] representative, has been sent to this venue on the [[President of the United States]]' behalf. Later that day at the hotel lounge, Burbank's ex-husband{{rp|113}} Harry Wolff plans to re-schedule the Cavett interview, due to difficulties with Brill during her profile. The moment Burbank heads to her room, Gil Gainey (a minor candidate) stops her and debates on the worth of her strategy. On the morning of the second day, several conventioneers notice a seemingly dead body sunk to the bottom of the pool from their balconies. Harry Wolff and the President's advisor on health, Gloria Burbank, are chatting by the deep end of the pool. Gloria then dives into the pool, not realizing there is a body floating on the bottom. As she approaches it, she finally sees it and screams in fear, heading back to the surface. Some other men dive in to rescue the drowned body, but it turns out that Gainey had been using an [[oxygen tank]] in order to play a [[publicity stunt]].{{rp|113}} That night, Garnell announces a serious message from the top of the hotel through her loudspeaker; many guests take notice, and some complain. Around that time, a businessperson named Colonel Cody arrives at the conference, and heads to Garnell's room to interrogate and find out her plans. Next morning, Harry finds out that Burbank is beginning to support Garnell, and thinks that this is not right. Later on, while discussing [[breastfeeding]] and [[abortion]] with Brill, Burbank is astonished that Garnell and Brill were actually born male. After serving in the [[United States Army|Army]], both had [[sex reassignment surgery|sex change operations]] in 1960. Bobby Hammer, a dirty tricks specialist, actually concocted this revelation to trick Burbank.{{rp|82}} After another discussion with Brill, Burbank enters the empty convention hall, where Cody interrupts her. He finds her title, and the ideals of the HealtH organization, worthless. Ashamed and in tears, Burbank is shocked that he controls not only HealtH, but also the ongoing election; he even plans to [[vote rigging|rig the votes]] and the outcome. She runs back to tell Wolff on Cody's scheme. As the couple start making love, Burbank is worried that it will be all over for her if Garnell wins. Harry, however, assures her that Garnell is still a woman anyway. On the fourth and final day, the results of the HealtH election are announced live on Cavett's show, and Esther Brill comes out as the victor. Burbank and her ex-husband watch on from their balcony outside, and also take a glimpse at Cody proposing an offer to Brill. Some time later, Cody, who turns out to be her harmless nut brother, gets into a fit of anger, knocking down everything in his path, and demands to get away immediately. With the HealtH convention over, another one involving [[hypnosis|hypnotists]] is taking root at the hotel.{{cite book|last=Kolker|first=Robert Phillip|title=A Cinema of Loneliness: Penn, Stone, Kubrick, Scorsese, Spielberg, Altman|isbn=0-19-512350-6|year=2000|edition=3rd|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|url=https://archive.org/details/cinemaofloneline00kolk}}{{rp|385}} Before he and the candidates leave, Cavett briefly greets Dinah Shore,{{cite book|last=McGilligan|first=Patrick|title=Robert Altman: Jumping Off the Cliff|url=https://archive.org/details/robertaltman00patr|url-access=registration|isbn=0-312-30467-6|year=1989|publisher=[[St. Martin's Press]]}}{{rp|476}} the host on hand for this event.{{rp|385}} As the HealtH sign is taken down in front of the hotel, the Steinettes perform a Broadway-style [[show tune]] that closes the film. ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:center; margin: 5px;" |- ! style="background:darkGrey; width:155px;"|Name ! style="background:darkGrey; width:137px;"|Character ! style="background:darkGrey; width:200px;"|Description ! style="background:darkGrey; width:30px;"|Source |- | [[Carol Burnett]] || Gloria Burbank || A candidate for the HealtH election, and a White House representative. She becomes [[sexual arousal|sexually aroused]] whenever she is frightened.{{rp|383}}

is the most popular pick for the election; her motto is "Free Yourself".{{rp|383}} Suffering from narcolepsy, she drifts into sleep every time she tries finishing a sentence, and also believes that [[orgasm]]s shorten a woman's life by 28 days.{{rp|383}} |- | [[Glenda Jackson]] || Isabella Garnell || Brill's rival in the HealtH campaign,{{rp|383}} she borrows her speeches from Illinois governor [[Adlai Stevenson II|Adlai Stevenson]]{{rp|113}} and commits her thoughts to a [[tape recorder]].{{rp|383}} |- | [[James Garner]] || Harry Wolff || Gloria Burbank's ex-husband,{{rp|113}} and Esther Brill's campaign manager.{{rp|383}} |- | [[Paul Dooley]] || Dr. Gil Gainey || A salesperson for "Vita-Sea", a powdered [[kelp]] product.{{rp|113}} Twice in the film, he pretends to drown in a pool in York City|New York]],{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vQ4OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PnwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5343,369164&dq=health+robert-altman&hl=en|last=Clark|first=Roy Peter|title=Carol Burnett, Glenda Jackson ready to go to work on 'HEALTH'|date=1979-02-16|accessdate=2010-05-01|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]}}{{rp|1-D}} who are dressed in different outfits during the convention. Gerard Plecki calls their songs "ironic commentary on the health crisis implied in the film".{{rp|113}} |- | Julie Janney |- | Patty Katz |- | Diane Shaffer |} ==Production== [[File:Don Cesar.jpg|thumb|Robert Altman shot ''HealtH'' at the [[Don CeSar]] hotel, [[St Petersburg Beach]], Florida.|alt=A pink, multi-floor hotel stands out above a calm sea and a windswept beach.]] Under the supervision of [[Alan Ladd, Jr.]], head of 20th Century-Fox,{{rp|128}} director Robert Altman made ''HealtH'' for US$6 million{{rp|84}} through his Lion's Gate Films company (unrelated to [[Lionsgate|the present-day firm based in Vancouver]]).{{rp|xxviii}} At the time, Altman had commitments to deliver films for Fox until 1981;{{rp|113}} ''HealtH'' was his fifteenth feature project.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=u3MjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lGcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4611,3400308&dq=health+robert-altman&hl=en|last=Huisking|first=Charles|title=Regarding Robert Altman's 'Health'|date=1979-02-23|accessdate=2010-05-01|work=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]|page=1-C}} "[Alan] had great faith in me," he told [[David Sterritt]] in 2000; "he put his own job on the line."{{rp|128}} Of the film's timing, he said, "''HealtH'' could have only been made when it was made, and that was the end of the [[Jimmy Carter|Carter]] era." This and 1979's ''[[Quintet (film)|Quintet]]'' were Altman's first collaborations with writer Frank Barhydt;{{rp|608, 612}} the two would later work on the 1988 HBO miniseries ''[[Tanner '88]]'',{{rp|xxxiii}} as well as 1993's ''[[Short Cuts]]''{{rp|xxx}} and 1996's ''[[Kansas City (1996 film)|Kansas City]]''.{{rp|xxxi}} In response to the diminishing box office returns of his last three efforts (''[[A Wedding]]'', ''Quintet'' and ''[[A Perfect Couple]]''), and in case any delays could put a damper on his financing, Altman rushed ''HealtH'' into production.{{rp|81}}{{rp|475}} The film was shot in sequence{{rp|113}} at only one location:{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19810213&id=FPALAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K1oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5421,3563464|last=Ross|first=Robert Alan|title=Altman's anemic 'HEALTH' shown on cable television|date=1981-02-13|accessdate=2010-05-01|work=St. Petersburg Times|page=3D}} the [[Don CeSar|Don CeSar Beach Hotel]] in St Pete Beach, Florida.{{rp|113}} Production began on February 20, 1979, and continued for three months.{{rp|113}}{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/650156742.html?dids=650156742:650156742&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Apr+29%2C+1979&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=ALTMAN+IN+A+STATE+OF+'HEALTH'&pqatl=google |last=McLeod|first=Michael J.|title=Altman in a State of 'HealtH'|date=1979-04-29|accessdate=2010-04-30|url-access=registration |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=N1}} The crew chose the Don CeSar, said Altman, because "we felt [this] would be fun, with lots of crazy situations and off-beat characters." [[Joseph Byrd]] worked on the music score,{{rp|612}} along with supervisor [[Allan F. Nicholls|Allan Nicholls]].{{rp|474}} To capture the authenticity of the convention in the movie, art director Bob Quinn and co-writer Frank Barhydt visited an actual one in [[Boston]], Massachusetts before shooting. Over one hundred health food companies contributed to the set. One of them, Sovex Granola, participated during the shoot; their scenes did not make it into the finished film, but they received end-credit billing.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JMMk4pl4LB4C&pg=PA23&dq=Robert+Altman's+HealtH&hl=en|last=Richmond|first=Akasha|title=Hollywood Dish: More Than 150 Delicious, Healthy Recipes from Hollywood's Chef to the Stars|isbn=1-58333-241-3|page=23|year=2006|accessdate=2010-05-01|publisher=[[Penguin Group|Avery]]}} Robert Altman was known to wear different hats on every new production of his;{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/robertaltmanoral0000zuck|url-access=registration|quote=hat.|last=Zuckoff|first=Mitchell|title=Robert Altman: The Oral Biography|page=[https://archive.org/details/robertaltmanoral0000zuck/page/302 302]|isbn=978-0-307-26768-9|year=2009|accessdate=2010-05-01|location=New York|publisher=[[Alfred A. Knopf]]/[[Random House]]}} on the set of ''HealtH'', he wore a straw one.{{rp|3-D}} While filming, Altman got into a conflict with members of the local [[Teamsters]] branch,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DIosAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8foDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6938,5223045&dq=health+robert-altman&hl=en|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120714032410/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DIosAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8foDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6938,5223045&dq=health+robert-altman&hl=en|url-status=dead|archive-date=2012-07-14|author=Knight News Service|title=A Day in the Life of Robert Altman, Director|date=1979-04-29|accessdate=2010-04-30|work=[[The Ledger|Lakeland Ledger]]|page=5E}} and had to pay "outrageous salaries" for certification.{{rp|486}} Garner recalled "we had a lot of fun making it... I loved Bob Altman."{{cite book|title=The Garner Files: A Memoir|first1=James|last1=Garner|first2=Jon|last2=Winokur|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=2011|page=259}} A short while after ''HealtH'' finished production, producer [[Robert Evans (producer)|Robert Evans]] hired Altman for a musical version of ''[[Popeye (film)|Popeye]]'', co-produced by [[Paramount Pictures]] and [[Walt Disney Pictures|Walt Disney Productions]].{{rp|84, 86}} Altman went to [[Malta]] to shoot the film,{{cite book|last=Duchovnay|first=Gerald|title=Film Voices: Interviews from Post Script|isbn=0-7914-6156-4|year=2004|publisher=[[SUNY Press]]}}{{rp|17}} and brought the Steinettes from ''HealtH'' along with him.{{rp|506}} ==Release== [[File:Theateroutsidepub.jpg|thumb|New York's [[Film Forum]] screened ''HealtH'' in April 1982.|alt=The front of a movie theater, with bright lights at the entrance and a blue backdrop on the second and third floors. The marquee is advertising a film by Ousmane Sembène and the original "Solaris" from 1972.]] Distributor 20th Century-Fox originally planned ''HealtH'' for a Christmas 1979 release.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmthreat.com/features/2239/|last=Hall|first=Phil|title=Bootleg Files 243: "HealtH"|date=2008-07-25|accessdate=2010-04-30|work=[[Film Threat]]|publisher=Hamster Stampede LLC}} But by the time editing was complete,{{rp|17}} a change of management took place at the studio,{{rp|474}} and Alan Ladd, Jr. was among those to leave;{{rp|84}} as a result, Fox shelved the film. After canceling plans for a March debut in January 1980,{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/622913032.html?dids=622913032:622913032&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Jan+23%2C+1980&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Tempo&pqatl=google|last=Beck|first=Marilyn|title=What they're doing to 'Health' probably makes Altman sick|date=1980-01-23|accessdate=2010-04-30|url-access=registration |work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=B7}} they moved it to their summer schedule;{{rp|17}} Altman's strategy was to have the film released in time for [[1980 United States presidential election|that year's presidential campaign]].{{rp|19}} Before that could take place, the company's new president, Norman B. Levy, planned an April 1980 run in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. Altman went against it and suggested test runs in four markets instead: [[San Francisco]] and [[Sacramento]], California; [[Houston]], Texas; and Boston, Massachusetts. The resulting previews played to poor audience response, and some time later, Fox deemed it uncommercial for release.{{rp|82}} In the end, the company replaced it on their schedule with ''[[Oh! Heavenly Dog]]'', a crime comedy starring [[Chevy Chase]] and [[Benji]] the dog.{{rp|19}} Save for [[Sherry Lansing]], who loved the film, Robert Altman had a fallout with Fox personnel over their handling of ''HealtH''.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/18/movies/film-view-robert-altman-an-endangered-species.html|last=Canby|first=Vincent|authorlink=Vincent Canby|title=Film View; Robert Altman—An Endangered Species|date=1982-04-18|accessdate=2010-04-30|work=New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|page=D17}} After filming ''Popeye'', Altman tried to contact Norman Levy on its status. The filmmaker complained, "[Levy] didn't return my phone calls for seven weeks. That's just basic rudeness. I don't think he knows what a movie is anyway." Moreover, he said of the studio's distribution unit: "Norman Levy and the rest are scum. [...] They're not interested in movies. They're interested in [[ski lift]]s and [[Coca-Cola]]." Amid this situation, Altman began to distribute ''HealtH'' on his own{{rp|329–330}} by taking it to the [[film festival]] circuit.{{rp|115}} The comedy was screened at the [[Montreal Film Festival]] in August 1980,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gMocAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vloEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2055,4493069&dq=health+robert-altman&hl=en|title=FILM FESTIVALS...some good, some bad, some special|date=1980-08-29|accessdate=2010-04-30|work=The Sherbrooke Forum|page=Forge 11}} and later appeared at [[Telluride Film Festival|Telluride]]{{rp|84}} and [[Venice Film Festival|Venice]].{{rp|115}} Of the response at those venues, the director said: "It has a love-hate reaction—but what's wrong with that?"{{rp|84}} By September 1980, the festival exposure prompted 20th Century-Fox to hold over a month of preview screenings at the [[Regal Entertainment Group#United Artists Theaters|UA Theater]]{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/658225292.html?dids=658225292:658225292&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+14%2C+1980&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Other+125+--+No+Title&pqatl=google|title=CALENDAR|date=1980-09-14|accessdate=2010-04-30|url-access=registration |work=Los Angeles Times|page=T37}} in [[Westwood, Los Angeles, California|Westwood, Los Angeles]];{{rp|115}} a nationwide release was also considered.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PbsNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hVoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5781,281560&dq=health+robert-altman&hl=en|last=Beck|first=Marilyn|title=Film clips (Beck on Hollywood personalities)|date=1980-09-01|accessdate=2010-04-30|work=St. Petersburg Times|page=3D}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aYwuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8ocFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2753,8835297&dq=health+robert-altman&hl=en|author=[[Associated Press]] (AP)|title=Robert Altman's latest film is in ill health|date=1980-09-30|accessdate=2010-04-30|work=[[Tri-City Herald]]|page=Ent. 11}} Despite even worse acclaim this time, Altman remarked that this run "did respectable business, considering that there was no advertising. But it's finished, dead, buried."{{rp|83–84}} Ultimately, ''HealtH'' would be Altman's last film for Fox;{{rp|81}} his experiences would later convince him to skip major distribution for ''[[Come Back to the Five and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean (film)|Come Back to the Five and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean]]''.{{rp|129}} On March 7, 1981, a [[16 mm film|16 mm]] print of ''HealtH'' was shown at the facilities of [[Northwestern University]] in [[Evanston, Illinois]].{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/630984472.html?dids=630984472:630984472&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+15%2C+1981&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=MOVIES&pqatl=google|last=Siskel|first=Gene|authorlink=Gene Siskel|title=Poor 'Health' gets strange but robust local premiere|date=1981-03-15|accessdate=2010-04-30|url-access=registration |work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=D12}} The film also received a screening in [[Baltimore]], Maryland, on March 28.{{rp|17}} On April 7, 1982, it received its official cinema opening at the [[Film Forum|Film Forum 1]] in New York City. The film was released in at least two European markets: in Germany under the title ''Der Gesundheitskongress'',{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5upkAAAAMAAJ&q=Altman+-+HealtH&dq=Altman+-+HealtH&lr=lang_de|author1=Klein, Thomas|author2=Thomas Kobener|title=Robert Altman: Abschied vom Mythos Amerika|page=240|isbn=3-9806528-3-1|language=German|year=2006|accessdate=2010-05-10|publisher=Bender}} and in the United Kingdom, where prints ran a few minutes longer than the original U.S. cut.{{rp|131, 135}} ''HealtH'' aired on the Philadelphia-based [[PRISM (TV network)|PRISM]] [[pay television|pay-TV service]] in February 1981,{{cite journal|url=https://www.questia.com/?docId=96530080|last=Wyatt|first=Justin|title=Economic Constraints/Economic Opportunities: Robert Altman as Auteur|year=1996|accessdate=2010-05-01|url-access=subscription |journal=Velvet Light Trap|volume=n/a|publisher=[[Questia Online Library|Questia Media America Inc.]]}} and also on the national U.S. outlet [[The Movie Channel]] that same year. The film was also broadcast on the [[CBS]] network in August 1983.{{rp|115}}{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/637119832.html?dids=637119832:637119832&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Aug+16%2C+1983&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Tempo&pqatl=google|last=Flander|first=Judy|title=TV highlights: Burnett, the triple threat|date=1983-08-16|accessdate=2010-05-06|url-access=registration |work=Chicago Tribune|page=B5}} As of 2010, a [[widescreen]] version has been shown on basic cable's [[Fox Movie Channel]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefoxmoviechannel.com/movie_details.php?id=79L0008|title=Program details for ''H.E.A.L.T.H.'' (1979)|accessdate=2010-05-01|publisher=Fox Movie Channel ([[News Corporation (1980–2013)|News Corporation]])|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129174917/http://thefoxmoviechannel.com/movie_details.php?id=79L0008|archive-date=2010-11-29|url-status=dead}} [[20th Century Fox Home Entertainment]] has not released the film on VHS, DVD or Blu-Ray. ==Reception== On the day of the film's Los Angeles opening on September 12, 1980, a review from [[Charles Champlin]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described the film as "essentially a revue sketch, giving the boys and girls of the chorus a chance to dress up funny and mill about. All a revue sketch needs is a thin premise, a point of view and an exit line. But having only one out of three won't make it for a movie." He concluded, "If indeed Altman weren't so original and so talented, an indulgent mess like ''HealtH'' would merely be another unsuccessful film in a bad year. It is instead mournful and exasperating in about equal measure."[[Charles Champlin|Champlin, Charles]] (September 12, 1980). "Altman's 'Health' Arrives". ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Part VI, p. 8-9. At the time of the Film Forum premiere, ''[[The New York Times]]''' [[Vincent Canby]] wrote: "''HealtH'' is, I suppose, a mess, but it is a glorious one in the recognizable manner of a major film maker who sometimes gets carried away—by his subject, by his own enthusiasms and those of his actors, and by the collaborative creative process he loves. As do so many of his films, ''HealtH'' gives one the feeling of being on a nonstop party with the people who made it." He added that it "is no masterpiece, but it is one of the most appealing entertainments that Mr. Altman has ever put together". In a later article, he declared: "''HealtH'' deserves to be seen by anyone interested in the career of this most eccentric and unpredictable of contemporary American film directors." [[Gene Siskel]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' called it "a pretty bad movie" and "anemic. Altman sets himself up as superior to his insipid characters, laughs at them, and invites us to do likewise. That's not much of an achievement." [[Leonard Maltin]] gave ''HealtH'' two stars out of four in his ''Movie Guide'', and added: "Non-Altman fans may love this more than devotees; Woodard steals the film—no easy feat considering that incredible cast—as [the] hotel's ultra-patient manager." ''Halliwell's Film Guide'' referred to it as a "zany satirical all-star romp on the lines of ''A Wedding'' but by no means as likeable or laughable, considering its cast, as it should be".{{cite book|editor=Gritten, David|title=[[Halliwell's Film Guide]] 2008|chapter=Health (*)|page=519|isbn=0-00-726080-6|year=2007|location=[[Hammersmith]], London|publisher=[[HarperCollins]] Publishers}} The ''Film Bulletin'' called it a "misfired satire", and commented that its "major stars [...] are otherwise wasted".{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iasqAQAAIAAJ&q=Altman+-+HealtH+-+satire&lr=&client=firefox-a&cd=39|title=HealtH|volume=49|year=1980|accessdate=2010-05-10|work=Film Bulletin|publisher=Wax Publications}} In a 1985 book on Altman, Gerard Plecki called ''HealtH'' "a humorous companion piece to ''Nashville''", adding that it "was certainly a major improvement over his two previous films".{{rp|113}} In regards to the studio shelving the film, Plecki remarked that it "certainly deserved mass marketing and a large promotion campaign".{{rp|115}} On June 12, 1982, U.S. President [[Ronald Reagan]] screened the film at [[Camp David]] during stormy weather. In [[The Reagan Diaries|his diaries]] that day, he called it "the world's worst movie".{{cite book|last=Reagan|first=Ronald|authorlink=Ronald Reagan|title=[[The Reagan Diaries]]|editor=Douglas Brinkley|chapter=June 12, 1982|page=88|isbn=0-00-726305-8|year=2007|accessdate=|location=New York|publisher=HarperCollins}} ==Themes== Since its release, ''HealtH'' has been viewed as a parody, and satire, of the U.S. political scene at the time of its filming; critic Daniel O'Brien also noticed "the parallels between the [HealtH] election and the U.S. Presidency explicitly spelt out (several times)" in the film.{{rp|82}} In his book ''A Cinema of Loneliness'', Robert Phillip Kolker stressed this aspect, writing that "Altman creates a world that is a parody of a political phenomenon that is itself already a parody of show business, for political conventions always mediate the realities of power with the signifiers of spectacle. ''[HealtH]'' is, finally, a representation of a representation."{{rp|384}} Kolker also observed Altman's use of the [[carnivalesque]], a style from Russian critic [[Mikhail Bakhtin]] that the filmmaker employed in many of his productions.{{rp|382}} O'Brien called this the film's "strongest asset [...], complete with [[huckster]]s and suckers (a handy [[metaphor]] for most aspects of American society".{{rp|84}} In Kolker's words, ''HealtH'' is "a hilarious documentation of politics and culture at the end of the Carter era when passivity began to disguise itself as self-satisfaction and marginal interests requested majority attention".{{rp|382}} The convention in the film "becomes a small mirror of larger political follies, of silly, self-serving people so convinced of their importance that they take for granted the fact that major significance attends their ridiculous activities".{{rp|382}} O'Brien noted that in ''HealtH'', "most of the main characters exhibit the expected Altman eccentricites", including the candidates in the election. "All this comes across as a little forced," he continued, "recalling the random weirdness of ''[[Brewster McCloud]]'' rather than the carefully etched [[idiosyncrasy|idiosyncrasies]] of ''[[The Long Goodbye (film)|The Long Goodbye]]'' or ''[[3 Women|Three Women]]''."{{rp|84}} Moreover, someone says "Hit it!" just before the convention band replaces the opening Fox fanfare.{{rp|384}} ==See also== *[[List of American films of 1980]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0079256|HealtH}} * {{amg title|id=126126|title=H.E.A.L.T.H.}} {{Robert Altman}} [[Category:1980 films]] [[Category:20th Century Fox films]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American political satire films]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Altman]] [[Category:Films set in Florida]] [[Category:Films set in hotels]] [[Category:Transgender-related films]]
